w:r.w:t: XMR rules to access the instances

To access the design components, follow the same XMR rules of Verilog. In System Verilog, dynamic data types (like class and covergroup) have been added and XMR rule is slightly different. The testbench program block can be considered as a leaf module. So program block instances can be accessed as same as design modules.
Whenever you access the generic dynamic data type, use “::” in front of the that.
In the above example env is a class name but my_gen is a instance.
Similarly cov_group is the name of the coverage group. If we need to access the instance of covergroup say “cov1” then the XMR will be as below
The table of contents above are can be automatically synced to your actual text by right clicking over the table and selecting “update field”.
Do not try to edit the table of contents directly

---Enter top level description here. Note that description paragraphs that are formated with the style “HVP description” will be interpreted by VMM Planner as the built-in description annotation. These descriptions are available to downstream tools like URG and DVE to display. Typically you will want to keep these sorts of descriptions fairly short---
shown above has a memory controller controlling 4 srams
are accessed by 2 CPUs. The CPUs access the system bus through a Round robin arbiter
and sends read or write requests to the memory controller
The two CPUs are part of testbench.
Other components are RTL and explained in detail in respective areas.
ile structure is as shown below. The important dir is tutorial/memsys/plans where there are two plans one for top level(memsys
ll the blocks are verified separately and the memsys is top level and
plan includes functional coverage (testbench cover groups)
The plan includes below important features
which can be useful in top level as well as block level. In this example sram has its own plan (subplan) and instantiated 4 times in this top plan.
eatures related with CPU Testbench (CPU0 and CPU1)

This attribute is defined in section “B Attribute Definition”

This can be choosen from “styles” in the word menus. There are 9 leveles of HVP Features already defined in this word document template for you.
All features are identified by styles of the form “HVP Feature *” where * is the hierarchical level of the feature.---

The HVP attribute phase is 2 since we are interested in this feature only during the top level verification and an override file will remove this feature for block level verification of individual components

since the sub features below define the measures
---The table below defines a measurement for this feature. metrics to measure
--- back to back transactions – 0 delay between cycles. This is indicated by the bins delay0. This feature is to show you we can go down to the bin level hierarchy ---
---above in the source “delay is a coverpoint and delay0 is the bin. Also notice the at_least parameter in the covergroup.---

--- coverage of delays between cycles. This is indicated by the bins delay_* meaning delay_0, delay_1 … delay_9 – automatically created since we have mentioned the bins as “bins delay[] = {[1:9]}” inside the coverpoint. So we may use the wildcard as “delay_*” in the source of the feature . ---
---above in the source “delay is a coverpoint and delay0 is the bin. Also notice the at_least parameter in the covergroup.---
